overview_of_class:
The seminar will investigate a wide array of visual art practices in the transatlantic world - from the 1830s (birth of Morse Code, telegraphy and photography) through the 1940s (WW2 and its aftermath) - that have imaged or in other ways referenced technology. A central question will be this: does a demonstrably technological or machinic iconography express an opinion on technology? Among the sources of artistic inspiration under scrutiny will be telegraphy, the railway, electricity-powered devices including lighting, construction equipment, the airplane, machines of war, high-tech architecture, and the automobile. The seminar will also investigate intermedial art forms whose production is technologized, e.g. intaglio printmaking.
